messageBody:
On Friday, June 2, 2006, at 7:35:39 PM, junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:

> Message: 7
> Date: Fri Jun 2, 2006 10:38 am (PDT)
> From: "James P Gunderson" jgunders@...
> Subject: Re: Digest Number 1846
>

> I am not a testing guru, but I (and our small company) try to be
> professional. As part of that our goal is to never release code that is
> untested, and we use the available tools to try to accomplish that goal.

> I have been reading this thread with interest, and am a little confused
> over the argument. I liked Bob Martin's analogy of double entry
> bookkeeping, and this may be part of the confusion. As far as I know, it
> doesn't matter whether the credit is put into the books first, or the
> debit is done first. The value of the practice is that both entries have
> to be done, and both must match. We do some test first, and some test
> second, but everything gets tested.

Testing everything is a good thing. An important difference between
TDD and double entry bookkeeping is that it /does/ matter whether we
do the test or the code first.

The most apparent reason is that the test is a /user/ of the code
and the code is an /implementer/ of the usage. So when we write the
test first, we are designing the interface to our code from the
viewpoint of a user and when we write the code first, we have (more)
the viewpoint of the implementer.

I often find that I'll write the first few tests a couple of times,
stopping part way through each one. I'll muse about how the object
should be built and called ... start writing the test ... not like
the interface ... change it.

Then I make that test work and do it again ... I learn more about
the interface ... perhaps change it again.

When I write the code first, I find that I'm less likely to change
it when I find it hard to use.

It could be just me. I'm not saying what I do is better -- I'm
reporting how it's different.

> In fact our model is a back and forth approach. We write a few tests
> based on a use case, and they fail. We write the code to support those
> tests, and (in the process) write support code to make the test driven
> code compile and pass it's tests. Then we write the tests for the
> support code, and the tests for the next use case, this leads to writing
> both the code to pass the tests, and some underlying code, which calls
> for a few more test cases. These latter tests are driven by the need to
> test corner conditions in the support code which may not be exercised by
> a specific instance of the use-case driven code.

> This back and forth approach seems natural, it reduced context switching
> in the design/implement domain, and seems to work well. What am I missing?

You may not be missing anything. Personally, I like the context
switching. It keeps my mind fresh, and ensures that I don't get
locked in on a direction that turns out not to be what it should be.

I have this unsupported theory that "corner cases" in my code
represent design flaws, so I try to produce code that doesn't have
such things. I could be completely wrong about that whole notion.

Ron Jeffries
